instruction: I need to bruteforce the SSH server at 192.168.1.100

tool_call.action_result: Hydra found 2 valid credentials: admin:password123 (admin access), root:toor (root access) after testing 10000 combinations

instruction: Crack these MD5 hashes from the database dump

tool_call.action_result: John the Ripper cracked 15/30 hashes in 45 minutes: password123, admin2024, qwerty, 123456 and 11 others recovered

instruction: Use GPU to crack these password hashes faster

tool_call.action_result: Hashcat GPU acceleration: 12345.6 MH/s on RTX 3080, cracked 8/20 hashes (40%) in 2 minutes - MD5 unsalted

instruction: I want to do a password spray attack without triggering account lockouts

tool_call.action_result: Password spray with 5 second delay between attempts: found 12 accounts using 'Summer2024!' across 1000 users, zero lockouts triggered

instruction: Attack the web login form on the admin panel

instruction: Bruteforce RDP on multiple Windows servers

tool_call.action_result: Medusa parallel RDP attack: scanned 256 hosts, found RDP on 45 hosts, compromised 8 accounts - Administrator, backup, user1

instruction: Generate a custom wordlist for this company's password pattern

tool_call.action_result: Crunch generated 45,697,600 passwords matching pattern 'Company' + 4 lowercase + 2 digits, saved to wordlist.txt (456 MB)

instruction: The database has SHA-512 hashes, crack them

tool_call.action_result: Hashcat SHA-512 cracking at 1234.5 MH/s: recovered 3/15 passwords - slower than MD5 but still effective with GPU

instruction: Test if users are reusing the password 'Welcome2024!'

tool_call.action_result: Password reuse test: 23 out of 500 users (4.6%) using 'Welcome2024!' - corporate password policy weakness identified

instruction: Attack FTP service to find weak credentials

tool_call.action_result: FTP bruteforce found: anonymous:anonymous, ftp:ftp, user1:password - 3 accounts with weak/default credentials

instruction: I have Kerberoast hashes, crack the service account passwords

tool_call.action_result: Kerberoasting attack successful: SQLService:MyP@ssw0rd!, BackupService:Backup2024 - 2 service accounts compromised

instruction: Use hashcat with rule-based mutations

tool_call.action_result: Hashcat with best64.rule: password -> P@ssw0rd, admin -> @dm1n, 5 additional hashes cracked through mutations

instruction: Spray test multiple common passwords

tool_call.action_result: First spray 'Password123!': 8 hits. Second spray 'Summer2024!': 12 hits. Third spray 'Company2024!': 5 hits - total 25 compromised accounts

tool_call.action_result: Medusa subnet scan: 256 IPs, 45 SSH servers found, 12 accounts compromised - admin, root, backup accounts with weak passwords

tool_call.action_result: john --show output: user1:password123, admin:admin2024, user2:qwerty, guest:guest - 4 of 20 hashes recovered so far

instruction: Attack the WordPress login page

instruction: Test common passwords against VPN

instruction: Use Medusa to test SMTP authentication

instruction: Create a wordlist with company name variations

tool_call.action_result: john --status: Session progress 67% (670000/1000000), Time: 5 min, ETC: 3 min, Cracked: 8/15 hashes (53%)

tool_call.action_result: hashcat -O --force enabled: Speed increased from 1234 MH/s to 1567 MH/s (27% faster), GPU at 98% utilization

instruction: Attack both SSH and FTP on the same host

instruction: Crack NTLMv2 hashes from responder capture

tool_call.action_result: NTLMv2 cracking: administrator::CORP:challenge:response cracked to Admin123! after 12 minutes at 450 kH/s

instruction: Test default credentials on all discovered services

tool_call.action_result: Default credential scan: admin:admin (3 hosts), root:root (2 hosts), default:default (1 host) - 6 systems with factory defaults

instruction: Generate wordlist based on leaked password patterns

tool_call.action_result: Pattern: 7 lowercase + 1 digit + ! (common requirement) - generated 7.8B passwords for breach-based attack
